instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 0V
threads.message:
Board had little corrosion on <CAPACITOR>C2740</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7825</CAPACITOR> other than that board is clean.

PPBUS 8.6V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 5V
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 0V
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 0V I get around 3V for a few seconds after I plug the charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 0V
threads.message:
Which big coils get voltage?
Inspect <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> for corrosion; remove it and resolder.
Also test desoldering <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 0V
threads.message:
<CHIP>U1950</CHIP> was clean but replaced it regardless, also removed <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> after replacing <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> and same result.

Only L7130 and L7560 get voltage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 0V
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 0V I get around 3V for a few seconds after I plug the charger."
Which other voltages (big coils) appear at same time?
Also check <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> pins in these few seconds.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 0V
threads.message:
All big coils get voltage for about 1 second, even vcore comes up.

<CHIP>U1950</CHIP> 
Pin 8 steady 3.4V
All other pins pulse for about 1 second.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 0V
threads.message:
Any pulse at <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>?
If not, check at <SIGNAL>CPU_VCCST_PWRGD</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>CPU_VR_READY</SIGNAL>.

Check all SPI Bus Termination resistors and their traces.
Inspetc J/<CHIP>U6100</CHIP> for corrosion.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 0V
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 0V no pulse
<SIGNAL>CPU_VCCST_PWRGD</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>CPU_VR_READY</SIGNAL>  both pulse around 1V

J/<CHIP>U6100</CHIP> are both perfect.

SPI Bus Termination resistors and their traces look perfect too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 0V
threads.message:
Heat CPU/PCH with quality flux.
Is possible to have accumulated crap underneath.

Just in case, test first starting in SMC bypass mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 0V
threads.message: That did not work, but UC did the trick, thanks a lot!
